channel.title: Essays on MillMint
channel.description: Recent content in Essays on MillMint

item.title: Landscape in the Age of Frustration
item.description: 🌺 Note from the Editor This article was originally published in October 2019. It offers an analysis of Evelyn Waugh’s Handful of Dust through an anti-utopian prism. 👒 Landscape in the Age of Frustration: Waugh’s Handful of Dust as Anti-Utopia # Hobart Phillips # Waugh’s A Handful of Dust has remarkable topography. The word can be extrapolated in this case in several ways; for one, the book is occupied by worldly, secular affairs, inextricably bound to a particular cultural landscape and absence of metaphysic.

item.title: Life as a Shill for Big Corporate
item.description: 🌺 Note from the Editor This article was originally published in November 2020. 💻 A Bite of the Apple: Petticoat Socialism and the Biggest Tech Company in the World # Hobart Phillips # I use Apple products as the primary interfaces for consumer tech in most parts of my life. I use an iPhone paired to an Apple Watch and AirPods on the go, a MacBook Air at home, and an AppleTV in the living room.

item.title: Not Long in Hong Kong
item.description: 🌺 Note from the Editor This article was originally published in October 2019. This article was written shortly after my return from Hong Kong, where I got caught up in the pro-democracy protests and is a broad response to Australian coverage of the ongoing events. 🇭🇰 Not Long in Hong Kong # Hobart Phillips # Hong Kong is a loud, bustling jewel of a city. It is perhaps my favourite city in the world.

item.title: A Cashless Tokyo
item.description: 🌺 Note from the Editor This article was originally published in December 2018. Yes, it’s painfully self-concerned and a little painful to read back, but for newcomers to the project you might find some “obvious truths” about Vekllei you have not yet encountered. 🗼 A Cashless Tokyo # Hobart Phillips # I did not come to Tokyo to find a reference for the Petticoat Project, because utopia does not exist there for me.
